scenarioDescription:
The Wolf 1061 Exoplanetary System


Overview

Wolf 1061 is a star with 0.29 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.31 times its radius. It is located 14.04 light years away from the solar system.

Wolf 1061 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the Wolf 1061 system


Wolf 1061 b

Wolf 1061 b was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2016-02, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Wolf 1061 b is 1.911 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Wolf 1061 b is 1.210 that of Earth. At 1.911 Earth masses, Wolf 1061 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Wolf 1061 c

Wolf 1061 c was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2016-02, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.09 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Wolf 1061 c is 3.412 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Wolf 1061 c is 1.660 that of Earth. At 3.412 Earth masses, Wolf 1061 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.


Wolf 1061 d

Wolf 1061 d was discovered by the La Silla Observatory observatory, in 2016-02, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.47 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of Wolf 1061 d is 7.705 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Wolf 1061 d is 2.690 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Wolf 1061 d is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Wolf 1061, which contains 3 exoplanets and was discovered by the La Silla Observatory.
name: Wolf 1061 - System With 3 Exolanets
